data.title: Bosnian Studies
data.text:
In lieu of an abstract, here is a brief excerpt of the content:

ConTRIBUTORS xi Hariz Halilovich is Professor of Anthropology and Principal Research Fellow at the Social and Global Studies Centre, RMIT University in Australia. He carries out research into people’s relationships to place and place-­ making processes after conflict, disasters, and migration. Intersecting this area of research is his research and writing on social memory: popular memory, contested and marginalized remembering and forgetting, traumatic memory, and performative enactments of commemorations and remembrances . He has written widely on the Bosnian diaspora, including his award-­winning book, Places of Pain: Forced Displacement, Popular Memory and Trans-­ Local Identities in Bosnian War-­ Torn Communities (2013). Asya Hekimoğlu received her BA from McGill University, Canada, before continuing her studies with a master’s degree in International Heritage and Law at the University of Kent in Canterbury, England. Her thesis looks at definitions of heritage through the lens of the Bosnian diaspora. She presently works for a charitable organization dedicated to building awareness of Canadian history, citizenship, and what it means to be Canadian. Hekimoğlu is based in Toronto. AidaIbričević is a political scientist and migration researcher. She is a Global Fellow with the Migration Center at the Peace Research Institute Oslo. Her research interests include citizenship, external voting, return migration, and high-­ skilled emigration. She holds a BA in Economics from Middlebury College, United States; an Economics MA from Central European University, Hungary; and a PhD in Political Science from Istanbul Bilgi University, Turkey. Her forthcoming book is Voluntary Return Migration to a Post-­ Conflict Society: Emotions, Citizenship, Home and Belonging in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Contributors xii Dino Kadich is a PhD candidate in Geography at the University of Cambridge, England. His doctoral research, rooted in feminist political geography , examines the emergence of “politics without a future” as a response to mass emigration and interminable gridlock in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a particular focus on youth. His publications and research interests explore art-­ academic collaborations, creative methods, and the politics of the digital world. Kadich is a diaspora Bosnian, born in Italy, raised in Arizona, and now perpetually on the run from the normative forms of belonging never quite available to him. Mišo Kapetanović is a Marie Skłodowska Curie Postdoctoral Fellow at the Austrian Academy of Sciences’ Institute for Habsburg and Balkan Studies, where he researches early ethnographic literature on same-­ sex affection and gender fluidity in the Dinaric Alps. He holds a PhD in Balkan Studies from the University of Ljubljana, Slovenia. Previously, he has worked as a researcher for Documenta—­ Center for Dealing with the Past in Zagreb and the University of Rijeka in Croatia, as well as the University of St. Gallen in Switzerland. He writes about working-­ class cultures in the Balkans, including labor migration (gastarbajteri), informal construction, and vernacular commemoration practices. Dženeta Karabegović researches and teaches at the University of Salzburg, Austria. She holds a PhD in Politics and International Studies from the University of Warwick, England; an MA in International Relations from the University of Chicago; and a BA (Hon.) in German and Political Science with a minor in Holocaust Studies from the University of Vermont. Her academic interests in political sociology focus on migration, transnationalism, diaspora, education, remembrance, transitional justice, foreign policy, and the Balkans. She consults with local and international organizations on diasporas and development, returnees, education, countering extremism, social entrepreneurship, and civil society. She was born in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and grew up in Berlin, Germany, and Burlington, Vermont. Ajlina Karamehić-­Muratović is an Associate Professor in the Department ofSociologyandAnthropologyatSaintLouisUniversity,St.Louis,Missouri. Contributors xiii She is currently teaching and researching at Zayed University in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. She holds a PhD in Health Communication from the University of Kentucky. Her interdisciplinary research is health- and community - focused, with an emphasis on the refugee experience and mental health challenges faced by refugees. She is a co-editor of Remembrance and Forgiveness: Global and Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Genocide and Mass Violence (2020) as well as of a forthcoming volume titled Intergenerational Trauma in Refugee Communities. Adna Karamehić-­Oates is the Director of the Center for Bosnian Studies at Fontbonne University in St. Louis, Missouri. She spent eleven years at the Open Society Foundations in Washington, D.C., in program management as well as in advocacy roles focusing on Central and Eastern Europe. She also served for seven years as Vice President and Treasurer for the Advisory Council for Bosnia-­ Herzegovina, an advocacy organization based in Washington...
